nodes.text: We do not  usually experience our selves ‘in essence’, as the philosophers  would say, but in relationships with other people and things. nodes.text: Vertical splits in the personality isolate self-regions, each  of which is capable of being an ‘independent centre of  consciousness’. Each is capable of producing a working model of  the-self-in-the-situation which takes account of some important  aspects of the self and leaves others out. It is mainly with vertically  splitting personalities that the present book is concerned

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: However,  we need a brief consideration of ‘horizontal splits’ (that is lids) for  comparison and perspective

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: ‘Horizontal splits’  (‘lids’) create repressed bits of self-imagery, or object-  representations, or self-object relations (Kohut 1971: 176ff.; 1977:  211ff.).

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: A central organization has to exist if repression is to be the  preferred defence against anxiety. Repression occurs when a  dominant central region does not integrate, but rather rejects,  information which would reveal an incongruity between it and  something that is about to happen.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: This dominant central  organization may be a self-image: I have either to give a penny to  the beggar or, conscious of incongruity, cease to regard myself as  a kind person.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: A more complex version of a repressive central process  involves an idealized image of the self. This region is not mapped  according to the contours of what I was or am, but according to  what I wish to be.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: In some  circumstances we may be so desperate for something that feels good  in a miasma of bad feelings, that we idealize another person, or try  for idealized relationship in which we can please the other.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: we are under pressure, both within and without, to  idealize our parents. And we are always under pressure to idealize  the loving relationship between parents and children

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: The pressures to idealize the marriage-  bond used to be as strong, but common sense has begun to prevail  in this area.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: Anxiety when the ideal and the actual are not congruous creates  the conditions for repression,

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: We then get horizontal splits.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: ‘Both the nature of the representational models a person builds  of his attachment figures, and also the form in which his  attachment behaviour becomes organised, are regarded in this  work as being the results of early learning experiences that start  during the first year of life and are repeated almost daily  throughout childhood and adolescence

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: On the analogy of a  physical skill that has been acquired in the same kind of way,  both the cognitive and the action components of attachment  are thought to become so engrained that they come to operate  automatically and outside awareness

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: Similarly, the rules for  appraising action, thought and feeling, and the precedence  given to each, associated with the concept of the super-ego,

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: are thought also to become engrained . . . and applied  automatically and outside awareness.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: Plainly this arrangement has both advantages and disad-  vantages. On the one hand, it economises effort and, in par-  ticular, makes no demands on the limited capacity channels  which mediate advanced processing.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: On the other hand there  is the disadvantage that, once cognition and action have been  automated, they are not readily accessible to conscious pro-  cessing and so are difficult to change.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: The psychological state  may then be likened to that of a computer that, once pro-  grammed, produces its results automatically whenever acti-  vated.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: Provided the programme is the one required, all is well.  Should an error have crept in, however, its correction not only  demands skilled attention but may prove trouble-some and  slow to achieve.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: Hence some of the difficulties encountered in psychotherapy.  For the task of changing an engrained programme of action  and/or of appraisal is enormously exacerbated when rules long  implemented by the evaluative system forbid its being re-  viewed.

ref.doc: JoKlein87 --our need for others and its roots in infancy __ Klein, J

nodes.text: An example of this is when people find themselves  unable to review the representational models they have built  of their attachment figures because to do so would infringe a  long-learned rule that it is against one or both parents’ wishes  that they should study them and their behaviour objectively
